name: rewind
content:
rewind verb
(GO BACK)
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ T or I ] to make a recording go back towards the beginning: Will you rewind that scene so we can watch it again? It is now possible to pause and rewind live television. She rewound to the beginning of the tape.
[ T or I ] to go back, or to make something go back, to an earlier time: We can't rewind history and try it a different way. Entering the baths is like rewinding eight centuries to Moorish days of old. Rewind to 2002 and an age of relative innocence.

In the past
rewind verb
(WRAP AGAIN)
[ T ] to wrap something around an object several times or twist it repeatedly around itself, for the second time or more: Having rewound the bandage, she put it neatly in the first-aid box. I looped the wool over two kitchen chairs, leaving my hands free to rewind the yarn on to cones.

Idiom
rewind the clock
a button that you press to make a recording go back towards the beginning: He would watch instructional videos, hitting rewind over and over to study the proper technique. Unfortunately, life doesn't have a rewind button.
